The initiatives of the Top American Latinx Tech Leaders are fully aligned with Reshma‚Äôs efforts. We look forward to working together to have more minority women in tech & to champion the causes that improve the quality of life for our communities. 

#Startups #Latinx #Diversity

When describing her motivation for championing her most recent effort; The Marshall Plan for Moms, Reshma shared one of the most powerful statements I‚Äôve heard in some time:
‚ÄúMothers should not be the safety net of this country.‚Äù

What I admire most about Reshma is her ability to be a disruptor on behalf of underrepresented communities. She is willing to challenge some of the most powerful figures in the establishment and bear the difficult pressures that come with it in order to bring change.

Reshma has and continues to build the biggest pipeline of future female engineers in the world.

Having lived in NYC for 20 years before moving to the Bay Area, I‚Äôve come to know of Reshma, not only as one of the most prominent figures in NYC, but as a staple of the city.

I am one of three brothers who are extremely fortunate to have as our only task to collect the fruit of the rich harvest planted by these three incredible women.

Love you Isabelita, Tita and Ma!

Throughout life some people are presented with a couple of decisions that can dramatically change their life in positive ways. Few people realize this at the time of making these decisions. She has an uncanny ability to spot these opportunities and make the right call every-time.

Grandma Helena, who worked as an EA to the highest ranking US military in the American Embassy in Colombia in the 50s-60s while raising 5 children (my mom among them).

And finally my mom, Astrid, from whom I learned everything I know about life, happiness & entrepreneurship.

This month I celebrate the three most influential women in my life:

Grandma Isabelita, who worked her entire career for the Military in Colombia after raising 7 children (my dad among them) as a single mother.
